title: Causal Associations of Adiposity and Body Fat Distribution with Coronary Heart Disease, Stroke Subtypes and Type 2 Diabetes: A Mendelian Randomization Analysis
author: Dale
author_address: Farr Institute of Health Informatics Research, UCL Institute of Health Informatics, University College London, 222 Euston Road, London, NW1 2DA, United Kingdom
hypothesis: Effect of body mass index and waist hip ratio adjusted for body mass idnex on cardiometabolic traits
rationale: Implications of different adiposity measures on cardiovascular disease aetiology remain unclear
exposure_population: European (Individuals of non-European ancestry were removed to minimise confounding by population structure.)
exposure_pleiotropy: Linear and logistic models with confounders
limitations_overall: Limitations include the potential pleiotropic effects of the multi-SNP instruments. However, results suggest little evidence for unbalanced pleiotropy
limitations_pleiotropy: With multi-SNP instruments, there is a chance that pleiotropic effects might become balanced such that causal inference regarding the exposure is possible. In this study we perform MR analyses of BMI and WHR together with recently developed methods that are robust to horizontal pleiotropy under additional assumptions. We therefore employ MR-Egger regression to provide a test for unbalanced pleiotropy and a causal estimate of exposure on outcome in its presence10, 11. In addition we use the weighted median estimator which can give valid estimates even in the presence of horizontal pleiotropy provided at least 50 per cent of the information in the analysis comes from variants that are valid instruments, and has the advantage of retaining greater precision in the estimates compared to MR-Egger12.
limitations_population_stratification: Not discussed
limitations_statistical_power: NA
notes: Performed MVMR as sensitivity: We found some evidence for association of both adiposity instruments with smoking, but not with other major confounders (Supplemental Table 16). To account for this, sensitivity analyses were undertaken for each cardiometabolic disease using multivariate MR including the effect of each SNP used as instrument for BMI and WHRadjBMI on smoking. MR estimates were found to be robust to this adjustment

title: Causal relationships between obesity and the leading causes of death in women and men
author: Censin
author_address: Big Data Institute at the Li Ka Shing Centre for Health Information and Discovery, University of Oxford, Oxford, United Kingdom, Wellcome Centre for Human Genetics, Nuffield Department of Medicine, University of Oxford, Oxford, United Kingdom, Program in Medical and Population Genetics, Broad Institute, Cambridge, Massachusetts, United States of America
hypothesis: Effect of body mass index on multiple disease outcomes
rationale: Previous studies have found causal relationships between higher BMI and WHR adjusted for BMI (WHRadjBMI) and type 2 diabetes (T2D) and coronary artery disease (CAD), using a limited number of previously known obesity-associated single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs). However, sex-specific relationships are largely unexplored as is the the role that obesity traits play in the leading causes of death beyond these cardiometabolic diseases.
exposure_covariates_model: Adjustments were made for baseline age, age2, array type, assessment centre, 10 principalcomponents, and sex if applicable, for all traits when in clinical units and for binary outcomes,and array and 10 principal components if rank inverse normal transformed (where adjustmentfor age, age2, assessment centre, and if applicable sex had already been performed in the rankinverse normal transformation of the residuals)
exposure_independence: We then pruned these SNPs for LD independence, so that not correlated SNPs from different sex-specific analyses would be included, and to obtain a set of the same SNPs for all sex strata. Independent SNPs were selected by taking all the SNPs specified as “index” SNPs in the men, women or combined-sexes analyses and then keeping the SNP with the lowest combined-sexes P-value within each 1 Mb sliding window for BMI, WHR, and WHRadjBMI separately. We later excluded SNPs based on long-distance LD (r2>0.05)
exposure_pleiotropy: Extensive re-analysis using differnet SNP sets and startification by smoking etc.
n_SNP_difference_reason: Not all exclusions explained. For all GRSs, any SNPs found to be non-biallelic in the UK Biobank were excluded (n=6, rs7798002, rs73646205, rs10828247, rs10892873, rs699370, rs805768), as this would violate the additive assumption. Four SNPs were also excluded as they failed post-imputation quality control (rs11500477, rs144926207, rs547943994, rs9638713). To further ascertain that there was no LD between SNPs in a GRS, we computed the r2 between all pairs of SNPs included in an instrument–for pairs of correlated (r2>0.05) SNPs included in the same instrument, the SNP in each pair with the highest P-value was excluded (rs1025395, rs9302652, rs8189480).
MR_sensitivity_method_results: Consistent with main analysis: A few of the GRSs used in the main analysis showed evidence of directional pleiotropy in the MR-Egger intercept test. The MR-Egger point estimates for all these associations were of lower magnitude than the point estimates from the main MR analyses. Despite this, for all the disease outcome MR analyses where one sex had significantly higher estimates than the other the point estimates using the IVW, MR-Egger, and weighted median methods were all higher in the same sex as in the main analysis. This indicates that the sex differences we see are robust using different MR methods to compute causal estimates
IV_strength: Lowest F stat of any GRS was 4,921. We assessed the strengths of associations between the GRSs and their respective obesity trait by computing trait variance explained and the F-statistics. First, we standardized the obesity traits by rank inverse normal transformation of the residuals after regression of the obesity trait on baseline age, age2, assessment centre, and if applicable sex, after any sample quality exclusions. This was done separately for men and women in the sex-specific analyses, but jointly in the combined analyses. For WHRadjBMI, we also adjusted for BMI. We thereafter performed linear regression, adjusting for array type and 10 principal components. Trait variance explained was defined as the increase in adjusted R2 by inclusion of the GRS in the linear regression model. F-statistics were computed using the formula F=((n-k-1)/k)(R^2/〖1-R〗^2 ), where n is the number of observations, k=1 for number of instruments, and R2 the unadjusted R2
replication_subsetting: Replicated in white british only subset. Consitent with main analysis
multiple_testing: For the obesity trait-disease analyses, the P-value threshold was set at <0.001 (= 0.05/51) for the total of 51 obesity trait-disease combinations investigated in the study. For the obesitytrait-risk factor analyses, the P-value threshold was set at <0.003 (= 0.05/15), for the total of 15obesity trait-risk factor combinations investigated in the study.
limitations_overall:
imbalances in the proportion of women and men
in included studies, differential availability of summary-level sex-stratified GWAS data and
the potential for biases to operate differentially between women and men pose additional complexities in deciphering underlying causal effects. It is possible that our genetic instrument for WHRadjBMI might show features of colliderbias whereby SNPs included in the GRS associate with both higher WHR and lower BMI leading to potentially spurious findings. Sensitivity analysis supported main findings. Different SNPs and weightings for SNPs all supported main findings.
limitations_pleiotropy: Performed extensive re-analysis using different SNP sets which were all consistent with main analysis
limitations_population_stratification: Results not generalizeable outside of Europeans. Recent studies have highlighted potential population stratification in both Genetic Investigation of ANthropometric Traits (GIANT) and UKBB. Another study has indicated that GRS distributions can differ slightly between different European populations. We therefore conducted analyses both in all Europeans (self-report of any “white” category) in the main analyses and in a subset of British participants only (in the “White British ancestry subset” as classified by the UK Biobank. The results were highly similar to those performed in all Europeans.
limitations_statistical_power: Samll case samples in cancers may have lead to weak power. In women, the effects of WHR were directionally consistent with harm, but the estimates were imprecise, probably reflecting insufficient powerin the sex-stratified analysis.

title: Type 2 diabetes, glucose, insulin, BMI, and ischemic stroke subtypes: Mendelian randomization study
author: Larsson
author_address: Stroke Research Group, University of Cambridge, UK and Unit of Nutritional Epidemiology, Institute of Environmental Medicine, Karolinska Institutet, Stockholm
hypothesis: Effect of body mass index, type 2 diabetes, fasting glucose, and fasting insulin on ischemic stroke subtypes
rationale: Stroke is one of the leading causes of disability and death worldwide. The burden of stroke is projected to increase considerably in the next decades. Hence, there is a need to develop effective prevention strategies for stroke, which necessitates a better understanding of the underlying risk factors
outcome_definition: Strokes defined by the Trial of Org 10172 in Acute Stroke Treatment (TOAST) classification system with confirmation with brain imaging
outcome_n_difference_reason: They excluded overlapping participants (but not clear how many or who else was removed) - plus, the numbers quoted in column S ("In the consortium/OG GWAS: size/case") are the total number of cases rather than subtype specific
limitations_overall: Because our MR study had limited statistical power to detect such a small increase in risk, we cannot rule out the possibility of a causal association between BMI and ischemic stroke. And they discuss general limitations including pleiotropy, canalization, population stratification, binary exposures and monotonicity assumption, variance explained (eg <3% in BMI) and therefore limited power.
limitations_pleiotropy: Pleiotropy (i.e., the genetic association with the outcome is through a different causal pathway and not via the risk factor of interest) could have influenced our results.
limitations_population_stratification: We cannot entirely rule out population stratification as a source of bias in this study. Nevertheless, restriction of the data to largely European-descent individuals reduced potential bias due to population stratification.
limitations_statistical_power: Thus, we cannot exclude that the lack of significant associations of fasting glucose, fasting insulin, and BMI with ischemic stroke subtypes is due to insufficient statistical power.
notes: Note that the sample sizes in the contributing GWAS are difficult to extract

title: The association between weight at birth and breast cancer risk revisited using Mendelian randomisation
author: Kar
author_address: Department of Public Health and Primary Care, University of Cambridge, Cambridge, UK
hypothesis: Effect of birth weight on breast cancer risk
rationale: Observational studies suggest that higher birth weight is associated with increased risk of breast cancer in adult life
outcome_study: Michailidou  2017 Breast Cancer  European and East Asian  female
exposure_pleiotropy: Took 41 of the 49 SNPs that were not associated with birth length, adult height, adult BMI, age at menarche, age at menopause, age at first birth, number of children ever born at P < 5x10-8
exposure_proxy: 28 SNPs, proxy SNPs in linkage disequilibrium with the BW-associ- ated lead SNP (r2 > 0.6 in European samples)
n_SNP_difference_reason: Took 41 of the 49 SNPs that were not associated with birth length, adult height, adult BMI, age at menarche, age at menopause, age at first birth, number of children ever born at P < 5x10-8
MR_sensitivity_method_results: Consistent with main analysis - Sensitivity analyses using four alternative methods and three alternative IVs, including an IV with 59 of the 60 BW-associated SNPs, yielded similar results.
limitations_overall: lack of strong associations between the other birth weight SNPs and age at first birth and number of children ever born, not being able to adjust for these two putative breast cancer risk factors in our multivariable MR is highly unlikely to have substantially altered the overall conclusion from our MR study.
limitations_pleiotropy: The BW-associated lead SNP at the 41 loci did not show genome-wide significant pleiotropic associations
limitations_population_stratification: Data on the association between BW and breast cancer risk in non-European populations is scarce
limitations_statistical_power: Genetic IV with maximum power (59-SNP IV) explained only 2% of the variance of BW, Horikoshi et al. study excluded individuals with extremes of BW (for the UK Biobank, which contributed nearly half the European sample, this was defined as < 2500 g or > 4000 g). Thus, the genetic IV we used may not adequately capture common genetic variants that only specifically affect the extremes of BW

title: Assessing the causal relationship between obesity and venous thromboembolism through a Mendelian Randomization study
author: Lindstrom
author_email: Department of Epidemiology, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA
author_address: saralind@uw.edu
hypothesis: Effect of body mass index on venous thromboembolism
rationale: Observational studies have shown an association between obesity and venous thromboembolism (VTE) but it is not known if observed associations are causal, due to reverse causation or confounding bias.
outcome_definition: In all studies, VTE (PE or DVT) was objectively diagnosed by physicians using different techniques including compression venous duplex ultrasonography, computed tomography, Doppler ultrasound, impedance plethysmography, magnetic resonance, venography, pulmonary angiography, and ventilation/perfusion lung scan. exposure_n_difference_reason: They just didn't report the number in their methods
n_SNP_difference_reason: So, they say that "Of those 97 SNPs, 77 reached genome-wide significance in European ancestry populations only (European ancestry-specific P values for the 20 remaining SNPs ranged between 6.0 × 10−8 and 6.1 × 10−6)." And three were not directly in the INVENT GWAS, with one being replaced by an LD proxy (R-squared = 1). I presumed this meant that they used 75 but actually they go onto say that "We then extracted VTE-specific effect estimates and P values from the INVENT GWAS for each of the 95 SNPs." This is the results of the sensitivity analyses where they use the 95
limitations_overall: Since our outcome was binary, there is a possibility that adjustment for covariates in the VTE analysis (in our case, primarily sex and age) will affect the causal estimate asymptotically as the coefficients from logistic regression are non‐collapsible (Burgess et al. 2016). However, this should not affect the validity of causal findings, provided that the instrumental variables are valid both marginally and conditionally on the covariates. A potential limitation of our study is the use of summary-level statistics rather than individuallevel data which would have allowed us to explore casual relationships in subgroups such as PE vs. DVT, smokers vs. non-smokers or women vs. men.

limitations_population_stratification: For the second assumption, the major potential confounder is population stratification. Although we included BMI SNPs that reached genome-wide significance in a multi-ethnic meta-analysis, our results did not change when we restricted our analysis to SNPs that reached genome-wide significance in European ancestry populations.
limitations_statistical_power: MR Egger regression has less power to detect a true causal effect in the presence of balanced pleiotropy

hypothesis: Effect of body mass index on multiple disease outcomes
rationale: Previous studies have found causal relationships between higher BMI and WHR adjusted for BMI (WHRadjBMI) and type 2 diabetes (T2D) and coronary artery disease (CAD), using a limited number of previously known obesity-associated single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs). outcome_definition:
Fasting glucose: plasma FG (in mmol/L, untransformed, corrected to
plasma levels using a correction factor of 1.13 if measured in whole blood in the original
GWAS)
exposure_n_difference_reason: Obtaining instruments from one sample, making a GRS in another sample, and using outcome from a third sample
exposure_covariates_model: Adjustments were made for baseline age, age2, array type, assessment centre, 10 principalcomponents, and sex if applicable, for all traits when in clinical units and for binary outcomes,and array and 10 principal components if rank inverse normal transformed (where adjustmentfor age, age2, assessment centre, and if applicable sex had already been performed in the rankinverse normal transformation of the residuals)
exposure_independence: We then pruned these SNPs for LD independence, so that not correlated SNPs from different sex-specific analyses would be included, and to obtain a set of the same SNPs for all sex strata. Independent SNPs were selected by taking all the SNPs specified as “index” SNPs in the men, women or combined-sexes analyses and then keeping the SNP with the lowest combined-sexes P-value within each 1 Mb sliding window for BMI, WHR, and WHRadjBMI separately. We later excluded SNPs based on long-distance LD (r2>0.05)
exposure_pleiotropy: Extensive re-analysis using differnet SNP sets and startification by smoking etc.
n_SNP_difference_reason: Not all exclusions explained. For all GRSs, any SNPs found to be non-biallelic in the UK Biobank were excluded (n=6, rs7798002, rs73646205, rs10828247, rs10892873, rs699370, rs805768), as this would violate the additive assumption. Four SNPs were also excluded as they failed post-imputation quality control (rs11500477, rs144926207, rs547943994, rs9638713). To further ascertain that there was no LD between SNPs in a GRS, we computed the r2 between all pairs of SNPs included in an instrument–for pairs of correlated (r2>0.05) SNPs included in the same instrument, the SNP in each pair with the highest P-value was excluded (rs1025395, rs9302652, rs8189480).
MR_sensitivity_method_results: Consistent with main analysis: A few of the GRSs used in the main analysis showed evidence of directional pleiotropy in the MR-Egger intercept test. The MR-Egger point estimates for all these associations were of lower magnitude than the point estimates from the main MR analyses. Despite this, for all the disease outcome MR analyses where one sex had significantly higher estimates than the other the point estimates using the IVW, MR-Egger, and weighted median methods were all higher in the same sex as in the main analysis. This indicates that the sex differences we see are robust using different MR methods to compute causal estimates
IV_strength: Lowest F stat of any GRS was 4,921. We assessed the strengths of associations between the GRSs and their respective obesity trait by computing trait variance explained and the F-statistics. First, we standardized the obesity traits by rank inverse normal transformation of the residuals after regression of the obesity trait on baseline age, age2, assessment centre, and if applicable sex, after any sample quality exclusions. This was done separately for men and women in the sex-specific analyses, but jointly in the combined analyses. For WHRadjBMI, we also adjusted for BMI. We thereafter performed linear regression, adjusting for array type and 10 principal components. Trait variance explained was defined as the increase in adjusted R2 by inclusion of the GRS in the linear regression model. F-statistics were computed using the formula F=((n-k-1)/k)(R^2/〖1-R〗^2 ), where n is the number of observations, k=1 for number of instruments, and R2 the unadjusted R2
replication_subsetting: Replicated in white british only subset. Consitent with main analysis
multiple_testing: For the obesity trait-disease analyses, the P-value threshold was set at <0.001 (= 0.05/51) for the total of 51 obesity trait-disease combinations investigated in the study. For the obesitytrait-risk factor analyses, the P-value threshold was set at <0.003 (= 0.05/15), for the total of 15obesity trait-risk factor combinations investigated in the study.
limitations_overall:
imbalances in the proportion of women and men
in included studies, differential availability of summary-level sex-stratified GWAS data and
the potential for biases to operate differentially between women and men pose additional complexities in deciphering underlying causal effects. It is possible that our genetic instrument for WHRadjBMI might show features of colliderbias whereby SNPs included in the GRS associate with both higher WHR and lower BMI leading to potentially spurious findings. Sensitivity analysis supported main findings. Different SNPs and weightings for SNPs all supported main findings.
limitations_pleiotropy: Performed extensive re-analysis using different SNP sets which were all consistent with main analysis
limitations_population_stratification: Results not generalizeable outside of Europeans. Recent studies have highlighted potential population stratification in both Genetic Investigation of ANthropometric Traits (GIANT) and UKBB. Another study has indicated that GRS distributions can differ slightly between different European populations. We therefore conducted analyses both in all Europeans (self-report of any “white” category) in the main analyses and in a subset of British participants only (in the “White British ancestry subset” as classified by the UK Biobank. The results were highly similar to those performed in all Europeans.
limitations_statistical_power: Samll case samples in cancers may have lead to weak power. In women, the effects of WHR were directionally consistent with harm, but the estimates were imprecise, probably reflecting insufficient powerin the sex-stratified analysis.

title: The role of glycaemic and lipid risk factors in mediating the effect of BMI on coronary heart disease: a two-step, two-sample Mendelian randomisation study
author: Xu
author_address: MRC Integrative Epidemiology Unit, University of Bristol, UK.
hypothesis: Effect of body mass index on coronary heart disease and potential mediators
rationale: The extent to which effects of BMI on CHD are mediated by glycaemic and lipid risk factors is unclear. In this study we examined the effects of these traits using genetic evidence.

limitations_pleiotropy: Horizontal pleiotropy is one of the major concerns in relation to limitations of MR studies. However, to explore the potential effects of this pleiotropy, we used different MR methods (IVW, medianbased estimators and MR-Egger) that have different assumptions and we assessed the consistency across each of these estimators. The mediators that we took forward into MR-based mediation analyses (triacylglycerols, HbA1c and type 2 diabetes) had consistent causal effects across these different methods for both steps (i.e. the effect ofBMI on them and of them on CHD). We tested for causal relationships between potential mediators prior to our main two-step MR analyses and these do not suggest any causal effects between triacylglycerols and HbAlc or other glycaemic traits.

rationale: Most studies of the obesity-depression association have used body mass index as a measure of obesity. outcome_definition: major depressive disorder as defined in PGC GWAS
outcome_study: Naomi R. Wray 2018 Major depressive disorder European both

limitations_overall: the UK Biobank measured fat and non-fat mass via bioelectrical impedance analysis (using a Tanita BC418MA body composition analyzer), which is considered less accurate than techniques such as dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry.
